Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 10:13PM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Sorry you have to be here!  Best wishes to you.  (wanted to say that first) My story is very similar to yours.  I'm 37, natural mother of 2, first child at 23, breast fed, no family history.  Found a hard, marble type, painless lump on the 8th, saw my OB/GYN on the 12th, diagnostic mammo and u/s on the 13th.  On the 15th my radiologist report stated there was a 2cm x 1.5cm heterogeneous solid lesion.  Gave it an ACR category 4 and suggested a needle biopsy.  I got my referral and saw my breast surgeon on the 20th and had the biopsy that same day.  On the 23rd I was diagnosed with invasive ductal breast cancer and had a partial mastectomy and my lymph nodes removed from the affected side on the 26th.  I'm still trying to catch my breath - but physically, I'm doing good.  I certainly hope your outcome is much better than mine.  Odds are in your favor.  Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Anyone who had a similar situation can you share your story? ihatescreennames whatisthis

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2009 12:00AM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Oh gosh, I'll take "anything" other than cancer!  My poor husband literally paces at times.  He spent the better part of the day outside putting new siding on our house and did the same thing yesterday too.  Tomorrow he says he's putting a new front door in along with a new full view storm door.  I guess the longer it takes for this to be over with, the better my house will look.  (haha)  Leaf - All I can say on the scar tissue theory is I don't think I've had an abscess that was backed up anywhere near this lump.  All I can do is hope that I'm wrong and that this is a very possible scenario for me - along with anything else benign.  If I could just get my mind wrapped around something that isn't cancer, I'd be doing ten times better than I am right now.  Geeze it's hard to get that word out of your head!  Renee - how excrutiating!  A whole month and not an answer, my gosh.  Is that a normal time frame??  I have to see my "tata doc" on Tuesday and I have no idea what to expect.  If she thinks I need a biopsy I hope it's done the same day.  I'd need nerve pills if she told me to come back in a week or two for the bopsy and then wait another week for results.  I'm hoping she looks at my films and says "oh this is benign something-or-other, go home and see me in a year".  Not too sure I wouldn't opt for a second opinion, but it would be nice to hear.    Good luck to you tomorrow and let me know how it goes!
Posts.Title: New Here - Worried Sick Lifeisbeautiful AnnaG

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 01:00AM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: BTW, Allvirgo, that pic is priceless.  LOL
Posts.Title: New Here - Worried Sick Lifeisbeautiful AnnaG

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 12:58AM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Well, I went to see my new doctor today and we didn't hear what we wanted.  She says that judging by her physical exam and my films that she believes I have "a breast cancer".  I don't know how many types there are and right now, I'm afraid to look.  She does think it's early though, so that's a plus.  She said her eyes aren't trained to see cancer on films so - I had my very first in life biopsy today - oh joy!  It wasn't too bad.  I had a hard time holding my arm in position, back behind my head and its still sore!  Over all though, the biopsy itself didn't hurt.  They did an u/s of my armpit and found some questionable lymph nodes but they were too deep to get an aspiration from.  They told me not to freak out about the nodes looking funny but WOW.. what are you supposed to think?  Like this thing has already spread through my body?  That maybe it started somewhere else and has shown an obvious face in my breast?  Now I swear every lymph node in my body aches.  Ugh.. this is horrible!  I go back for an MRI on Friday and she said she will compare the results of that with my pathology results and we will then decide on surgery and treatment options.  I pray it comes back not cancer.  Still holding onto that - but preparing for bad news anyway. I'm not going to cry again.  I'm not going to cry again.  I'm not going to cry again.
Posts.Title: New Here - Worried Sick Lifeisbeautiful AnnaG

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2009 10:58PM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: "I stick by the 10 day rule I read on this board, if it still hurts after 10 days then get checked." I like this.
Posts.Title: Signs of Mets Pure barbe1958
Memorial Sloan Kettering Study everyminute karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 02:44PM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Thank you very much, both of you, for the words of encouragement.  Can scar tissue show up anywhere in the breast, even where I've not had an abscess?  All of my abscesses have been on the sides and underneath of my breast - like where the bra edges rub.  This lump is on the top of my breast and unfortunately in what I would have considered the only "perfect" looking place I have left.  Hopefully scar tissue is all it is!  That would be great! Lisa, I take atarax for my hives and thankfully that keeps me controlled for about 6 days.  However, it knocks me on my rear - honestly - I could take one atarax and sleep for 16 hours.  My mother in law takes Allegra for her hives and from what you say, I believe her hives condition is very similar to yours.  Mine result from things brushing against my skin.  When I flare up, you can take your fingernail or the tip of a closed ink pen and write on my arm - a few minutes later what ever you wrote is written in hives.  It's the strangest thing!  I feel my hives coming on for about 3 days before I have to take a pill.   Thank you for the thoughts and prayers!!  ..and yes, life IS beautiful.
Posts.Title: New Here - Worried Sick Lifeisbeautiful AnnaG

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2010 11:59PM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: I got the Neulasta too, took the injection in my stomach because I heard it was easier on you that way.  Thankfully I didn't have any SE's from that ..well none that I could differentiate from the chemo.  I didn't have any long bone pain that I recall but I did have a headache.  I had stopped my caffeine intake too, which ended up being a horrible decision on my part.  My nurse told me that if I have a high caffeine intake to begin with, don't ever just stop because of chemo.  I think that made me feel awful too.  I sure hope there's something out there to help with that "sick" feeling I had in my arms and legs.  I wouldn't call it exhaustion.  Unless I've just never been exhausted before. *smile*  This was a completely new feeling to me. Glad you weren't nauseated.  I had some breakthrough nausea but found that if I ate something, most of the time that would take care of it within a few minutes.  I had to force myself to eat and when I wanted something, I wanted one particular thing and nothing else would do.  One day it was roast beef and another it was a plain ol' hamburger.  I ate a lot of red seedless grapes too and drank Sprite with cranberry juice.  Once I started feeling more like me again, which was on the 6th and 7th day post chemo, I was starving.  I mean like I hadn't eaten in a month.  I was a cooking at 5 in the morning FOOL.  And I cooked whatever we had in the refrigerator.  My sons thought I'd lost my mind because they always ate breakfast at school and here I was up and cooking at 5 AM.  My oldest was like "mom..  are you ok?"  LOL  Yep.  Eat and get your butt on the bus!
Posts.Title: AC side effect - WEAK Oogy Legs and Arms?? Lifeisbeautiful Lifeisbeautiful
Pathology Is Back - Cancer Lifeisbeautiful jenn3

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 10:19AM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Ok, I'm trying to keep my head together.  Today is also my oldest boy's 14th birthday, so I'm taking the good with the bad and trying to maintain.  I didn't mean to sound like my doctor was nonchalant.  She said that she would use a dye and that if any of the nodes were suspiscious, she would remove them.  She also mentioned the lymphedema too.  I'm sure she said more but you know that shock.  As soon as you hear you have cancer it's like the rest of what came out of her mouth was blah blah blah and was cloudy - not that I don't care because I DO but (insert endless string of profanities) it's just hard to get your mind unwrapped from the "C" word to see the big picture.  Right now I'm at the point of "today I'm alive and I feel good so let it go".  That is until I get a pain of some sort somewhere in my body and then wonder.. "are you cancer too"?  Then I wonder "what if my cancer doesn't respond to treatment" and "well if she removes the tumor and there's no sign of cancer in the nodes then am I good?" or "where else could the cancer be if she removes the tumor and the nodes" "where all in my body is this cancer right now".  It just doesn't stop.  Cancer is a mental torture and robs you of everything.  I get the feeling that my scrapbook room is going to be seeing a lot of me.  (I hope!!!) Oh, before I forget!  I am being treated at a teaching hospital.
Posts.Title: Pathology Is Back - Cancer Lifeisbeautiful jenn3

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 10:29AM Lifeisbeautiful wrote: Oh.. so If she thinks it's a grade 2 but the pathology says 3/3, 9/9 ESRB aren't those the same thing?  Could she be seeing something that leads her to believe it's not a 3 or am I confused?  She definitely said "2" - that much I remember.
Posts.Title: Pathology Is Back - Cancer Lifeisbeautiful jenn3
